item.title: Automatic Dialect Classifier
item.description: This project uses machine learning to detect the dialect a particular sentence belongs to. Currently, the model distinguishes between Mexican Spanish 🇲🇽 and Peninsular Spanish 🇪🇸. The model is trained on text data coming from subtitles of movies produced both in Mexico and in Spain. The project was conducted using Python. You can read more about it on this blog post or check out the code on Github.

item.title: Haiku Generator
item.description: This project produces a random haiku generator. By using texts coming from actual books, a Python script automatically extracts words and outputs a haiku (a text that follows the 5-7-5 syllable rule). Texts were taken from Project Gutenberg, an online library of more than 60,000 books. Among the Python libraries used for this project were SpaCy and SyllaPy. You can learn more about this project by reading this blog post or by checking out the code on Github.

item.title: Twitter Bot
item.description: This project creates a Twitter bot that would tweet the most played song in the world every day, based on data from Spotify charts. The bot lives here 🤖. To extract the relevant info from Spotify charts, the Python library BeautifulSoup was imported, which is used for web-scraping. Check out the code on Github to learn more about the project.

item.title: Experimental Linguistics with Ibex Farm
item.description: Ibex Farm 🐐 is an online resource that allows you to create psycholinguistic experiments that you can then send to participants. Ibex Farm runs using JavaScript, HTML, and CSS 💻. The cool thing about it is that it is highly customizable and it allows you to measure reaction times (RTs) and to randomize items, among other things. You can check out the Ibex Farm website here and its documentation here.

item.title: Heritage Language Writing
item.description: Heritage speakers are a specific type of bilingual speakers who grew up exposed to a home language different from the one spoken by majority in society. When heritage speakers start school, they learn the majority language which, in most cases, ends up being their dominant language 🗣️. item.title: Little Red Riding Hood Corpus
item.description: This corpus comprises several texts which are transcriptions of the Little Red Riding Hood fairy tale as narrated by different bilingual speakers. item.title: The Languages of Frida Kahlo
item.description: This project compares the English and Spanish subtitles from the movie Frida (2002) 🎥. Subtitle files were imported into R and examined using several natural language processing (NLP) tools and techniques, such as: Tokenization Bigrams Sentiment analysis Results were also plotted for a better interpretation 📊📈. Some of the packages used include: tidyverse tidytext stringi igraph ggraph syuzhet You can find the code here.

item.title: Structural Priming
item.description: Structural priming is the tendency to repeat or more easily process a syntactic structure that a speaker has been recently exposed to. Linguistic experiments that use structural priming try to understand how language is represented in the mind 🧠. This project used a structural priming paradigm to examine how different speakers (i.e., native speakers, second language speakers, and heritage speakers) process ditransitive constructions in Spanish. The experiment consisted of a pre-test, treatment, and post-test.
